texts.definition: Combos that consist of performing the same kind of action repeatedly a certain number of times within a certain time limit.
markups: <style="Definition">Combos that consist of performing the same kind of action repeatedly a certain number of times within a certain time limit.</style>

One way of making it more interesting to do the same activity many times in games is to create a specific reward for this. <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> is one way of doing this through giving rewards to players that have done an action a predetermined number of times within a short period of time.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Little%20Cave%20Hero">Little Cave Hero</link></style> all begin counting towards a <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combo</style> when players pick up rewards given for completing actions or goals. Meeting the requirement for the <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> result in more rewards.

Making high jumps repeatedly in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style> begins combo counts that when continued result in both individual rewards for each additional jump and a final extra reward.

Team Fortress 2 have several Repeat Combos, including the spy achievement You Only Shiv Twice (for backstabbing 3 enemies within 10 seconds), the engineer achievement Quick Draw (for killing a spy and two sappers within 10 seconds), the demo achievement ''Tam O'Shatter (for destroying 5 enemy engineer buildings during a single ÃœberCharge from a Medic), and the general achievement Flamethrower'' (for setting five enemies on fire within 30 seconds).

<style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> basically consist of choosing a type of action, a number of times it needs to be done, a <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limit</link></style> for doing these actions, and what <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> should be given for succeeding. Acquiring <style="Link"><link="reward-widgets">Reward Widgets</link></style> is a common example of the action needed, and is used in both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style> shows an example of using <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jumping">Jumping</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style> shows others still. While the first example is trivial and more an effect of having succeeded with previous actions, the two latter examples show that <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> can require skill.

Succeeding with <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> typically initiates new ones, creating <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> with an <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic Progression</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> are often created to make <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style> more rewarding, and <style="Link"><link="grind-achievements">Grind Achievements</link></style> are quite similar to <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> but do not have <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> associated with them. As the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style> examples above shows, they can however instead be the basis for <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style>.

To encourage players to try and achieve <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style>, their progress in completing them are nearly always shown as <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>. The exception is when many different types of <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> exist since this most likely clutters the game interfaces.

As the name implies, <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> are a form of <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>. Their representations are typically <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>. They are examples of <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style> besides often also being <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic Progression</link></style>.

The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Repeat Combos</style> quite likely makes <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style> more interesting by adding (additional) possibilities for gaining <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for doing it. When completing them can be noticed by others, e.g. through being <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style> or supporting <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style>, they can let players show their <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic Progression</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>
